title: How to Decorate a Kite

steps.headline: Glue on a rhinestone border to your kite to make it stand out.
steps.description: Add a strand of rhinestones to all 4 edges of your kite. Before adding any decorations, measure the edges of your kite and cut long, even strips of decorative border to match. After applying a long, thin line of super or tacky glue on the edge of the kite, stick the row of rhinestones onto the edge. For extra security, apply some pressure to keep the gems in place. If you don’t have any rhinestone strips on hand, consider gluing on rhinestones individually. You can find both individual rhinestones and rhinestone strips at your craft store. Feel free to use a lace border in place of rhinestones.

steps.headline: Add on some adhesive plastic charms for pizazz.
steps.description: Use a sheet of multi-colored, adhesive plastic charms and stick them along the inside of the kite’s border. Try to create a pattern with the charms and alternate them by color and shape. Continue all the way around until the inside edge of the kite border is filled with charms. If you can’t find any adhesive plastic charms, get a pack of regular, non-sticky charms instead. Use hot, craft, or school glue to add charms to your kite.

steps.headline: Finish off the kite with some sequins to make it extra shiny.
steps.description: Dab a few dots of school glue into the very center of the kite. While the glue is still wet, select a few bright and shiny sequins to put in the center. Apply a small amount of pressure to each sequin to make sure that they stay in place. Wait for the kite to dry completely before using it. Feel free to use this kite as a decoration, if you’d like! This type of kite decoration works especially well for Sankranti celebrations.

steps.headline: Place a sheet of printer paper on top of your tissue paper.
steps.description: Lay down a sheet of tissue paper onto a flat surface. Once you’ve smoothed it out, place a piece of printer paper on top, setting it 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) away from the edge of the tissue paper. For more exact measurements, use a ruler. Make sure the tissue paper edge is smooth, and not previously cut.

steps.headline: Slide an X-Acto knife down the edge of the copy paper.
steps.description: Slice off a strip of the printer and tissue paper with a precise knife cut. Once you’ve cut the strip lengthwise, repeat the process. Rotate the paper so it rests perpendicular to your initial cut. Hold the ruler and place and slice downwards with the X-Acto knife to remove the tissue paper strip. If you don’t mind the edges of your tissue paper being a little uneven, feel free to use scissors instead.

steps.headline: Cut the strips into smaller squares.
steps.description: Use a pair of scissors to cut your long strips of tissue paper into small, square pieces. Don’t worry about making all of the pieces identical. If you want your kite to look like a stained glass window, have your paper squares be slightly different sizes. Set these colored squares aside for later.

steps.headline: Stick strips of contact paper onto your kite to create a border.
steps.description: Measure the edges of your kite, taking note of the dimensions as you go. Take a sheet of adhesive paper and use scissors to cut out strips that match the length of your kite. To keep each piece consistent, measure and cut each strip to be at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide. Remove the backing paper to place the strips onto the kite. Apply even amounts of pressure with your hands to eliminate any wrinkles from the paper. Take your time during this process—since you’re working with 4 different strips to create the kite’s border, make sure that all of the strips are lined up exactly with the edge of the kite.

steps.headline: Paste small squares of tissue paper inside of your kite.
steps.description: Take the squares that you previously cut out and arrange them onto the center of your kite. Once you’re happy with their placement, use a glue stick or a dot of craft glue to secure each square into place. Try to have the squares overlap slightly to give the full stained glass effect. If you don’t care about having an exact pattern, feel free to glue on the squares as you go. To add an extra design element, cut 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) strips of contact paper to create the window panes.

steps.headline: Glue 2 googly eyes onto the front of your kite.
steps.description: Take a set of googly craft eyes and set them aside. If you want the face to be exact, set a ruler horizontally along where you’d like to place the eyes. Position the eyes on the kite to see if they’re even before gluing them into place. When doing this, only use a dot of craft or hot glue. If you don’t care about the details of the face being exact, feel free to glue the eyes in place without measuring.

steps.headline: Draw on a nose and mouth using permanent marker.
steps.description: Measure about 0.5 to 1 inch (1.3 to 2.5 cm) below the center of the googly eyes. Use a permanent marker to draw a small, dark triangle onto this spot. A few inches or centimeters below the nose, draw a curvy line to represent the smile. Depending on the size of your kite, these dimensions may vary. Ideally, the nose should be in the center of the kite.

steps.headline: Cut a small hourglass out of paper to use as a bow.
steps.description: Measure the top edges of your kite to figure out the dimensions for your paper bow. Once you have a length in mind, sketch an hourglass or bow shape onto a smaller piece of colored paper. Use scissors or an X-Acto knife to cut out the paper bows. For instance, if the top edge of your kite is 4 inches (10 cm) long, consider making the bow 1.5 to 2 inches (3.8 to 5.1 cm) long. If your kite is especially large, try and make the bows at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) thick.

steps.headline: Glue a paper bow onto each side of the kite.
steps.description: Dab a dot of craft glue or hot glue onto the center of the paper bow. Before the glue dries, press the bow onto the upper edge of the kite. Apply a small amount of pressure to secure each bow into place. If you’d prefer for your bows to look more exact, set them on the kite before gluing them in place.

text: Adding Rhinestones and Sequins Glue on a rhinestone border to your kite to make it stand out. Add a strand of rhinestones to all 4 edges of your kite. Before adding any decorations, measure the edges of your kite and cut long, even strips of decorative border to match. After applying a long, thin line of super or tacky glue on the edge of the kite, stick the row of rhinestones onto the edge. For extra security, apply some pressure to keep the gems in place. If you don’t have any rhinestone strips on hand, consider gluing on rhinestones individually. You can find both individual rhinestones and rhinestone strips at your craft store. Feel free to use a lace border in place of rhinestones. Add on some adhesive plastic charms for pizazz. Use a sheet of multi-colored, adhesive plastic charms and stick them along the inside of the kite’s border. Try to create a pattern with the charms and alternate them by color and shape. Continue all the way around until the inside edge of the kite border is filled with charms. If you can’t find any adhesive plastic charms, get a pack of regular, non-sticky charms instead. Use hot, craft, or school glue to add charms to your kite. Finish off the kite with some sequins to make it extra shiny. Dab a few dots of school glue into the very center of the kite. While the glue is still wet, select a few bright and shiny sequins to put in the center. Apply a small amount of pressure to each sequin to make sure that they stay in place. Wait for the kite to dry completely before using it. Feel free to use this kite as a decoration, if you’d like! This type of kite decoration works especially well for Sankranti celebrations. Creating a Stained Glass Look Place a sheet of printer paper on top of your tissue paper. Lay down a sheet of tissue paper onto a flat surface. Once you’ve smoothed it out, place a piece of printer paper on top, setting it 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) away from the edge of the tissue paper. For more exact measurements, use a ruler. Make sure the tissue paper edge is smooth, and not previously cut. Slide an X-Acto knife down the edge of the copy paper. Slice off a strip of the printer and tissue paper with a precise knife cut. Once you’ve cut the strip lengthwise, repeat the process. Rotate the paper so it rests perpendicular to your initial cut. Hold the ruler and place and slice downwards with the X-Acto knife to remove the tissue paper strip. If you don’t mind the edges of your tissue paper being a little uneven, feel free to use scissors instead. Cut the strips into smaller squares. Use a pair of scissors to cut your long strips of tissue paper into small, square pieces. Don’t worry about making all of the pieces identical. If you want your kite to look like a stained glass window, have your paper squares be slightly different sizes. Set these colored squares aside for later. Stick strips of contact paper onto your kite to create a border. Measure the edges of your kite, taking note of the dimensions as you go. Take a sheet of adhesive paper and use scissors to cut out strips that match the length of your kite. To keep each piece consistent, measure and cut each strip to be at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide. Remove the backing paper to place the strips onto the kite. Apply even amounts of pressure with your hands to eliminate any wrinkles from the paper. Take your time during this process—since you’re working with 4 different strips to create the kite’s border, make sure that all of the strips are lined up exactly with the edge of the kite. Paste small squares of tissue paper inside of your kite. Take the squares that you previously cut out and arrange them onto the center of your kite. Once you’re happy with their placement, use a glue stick or a dot of craft glue to secure each square into place. Try to have the squares overlap slightly to give the full stained glass effect. If you don’t care about having an exact pattern, feel free to glue on the squares as you go. To add an extra design element, cut 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) strips of contact paper to create the window panes. Making a Funny Face Glue 2 googly eyes onto the front of your kite. Take a set of googly craft eyes and set them aside. If you want the face to be exact, set a ruler horizontally along where you’d like to place the eyes. Position the eyes on the kite to see if they’re even before gluing them into place. When doing this, only use a dot of craft or hot glue. If you don’t care about the details of the face being exact, feel free to glue the eyes in place without measuring. Draw on a nose and mouth using permanent marker. Measure about 0.5 to 1 inch (1.3 to 2.5 cm) below the center of the googly eyes. Use a permanent marker to draw a small, dark triangle onto this spot. A few inches or centimeters below the nose, draw a curvy line to represent the smile. Depending on the size of your kite, these dimensions may vary. Ideally, the nose should be in the center of the kite. Cut a small hourglass out of paper to use as a bow. Measure the top edges of your kite to figure out the dimensions for your paper bow. Once you have a length in mind, sketch an hourglass or bow shape onto a smaller piece of colored paper. Use scissors or an X-Acto knife to cut out the paper bows. For instance, if the top edge of your kite is 4 inches (10 cm) long, consider making the bow 1.5 to 2 inches (3.8 to 5.1 cm) long. If your kite is especially large, try and make the bows at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) thick. Glue a paper bow onto each side of the kite. Dab a dot of craft glue or hot glue onto the center of the paper bow. Before the glue dries, press the bow onto the upper edge of the kite. Apply a small amount of pressure to secure each bow into place. If you’d prefer for your bows to look more exact, set them on the kite before gluing them in place.

Add a strand of rhinestones to all 4 edges of your kite.
Before adding any decorations, measure the edges of your kite and cut long, even strips of decorative border to match.
After applying a long, thin line of super or tacky glue on the edge of the kite, stick the row of rhinestones onto the edge.
For extra security, apply some pressure to keep the gems in place.
If you don’t have any rhinestone strips on hand, consider gluing on rhinestones individually.
You can find both individual rhinestones and rhinestone strips at your craft store.
Feel free to use a lace border in place of rhinestones.
Add on some adhesive plastic charms for pizazz.

Feel free to use this kite as a decoration, if you’d like!
This type of kite decoration works especially well for Sankranti celebrations.

Lay down a sheet of tissue paper onto a flat surface.

Make sure the tissue paper edge is smooth, and not previously cut.
Slide an X-Acto knife down the edge of the copy paper.
Slice off a strip of the printer and tissue paper with a precise knife cut.
Once you’ve cut the strip lengthwise, repeat the process.

Stick strips of contact paper onto your kite to create a border.

To add an extra design element, cut 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) strips of contact paper to create the window panes.
